article.headline: Montana State 63, Idaho State 56
article.story:
MISSOULA, Mont. (AP) -- The Idaho State women's basketball team
got over some first-half jitters to advance to the championship
game of the Big Sky Conference tournament with a 63-56 victory over
Montana State Friday night.

"I thought nerves would play a part in the way we might
start," said ISU coach Jon Newlee, who took over coaching a team
that won just six games last season. "You' say it's like any other
game, but it's really not. It's the semifinals, it's not a place
we've been before."

The Bengals (20-7) trailed 29-22 at halftime after shooting just
24 percent from the field and making just 1-of-11 3-pointers.

"I think our nerves showed in the first half," Newlee said.
"We were missing layups, missing open 3's. I challenged our
seniors at halftime and told Molly (Hays), 'You're not a freshman
anymore. We're at the end of the year.' Our backs are against the
wall, not theirs."

Idaho State opened the second half with a 13-4 run to take a
35-33 lead with 14:37 remaining.

"The first five minutes we climbed on the (offensive) boards
and finally played some defense," Newlee said.

Back-to-back baskets by Hutchison gave MSU a 37-35 lead with
13:21 remaining. The teams traded baskets until the five-minute
mark.

But by then, the fifth-seeded Bobcats (15-14) were playing
without center Belinda Stubbs, who had fouled out four minutes
earlier. The Bobcats also had leading scorer Kati Burrows on the
bench with a concussion suffered in a first-round game Thursday.
Another top scorer, Jana Smith, missed the final two weeks of play.

Molly Hays finished with 18 points and nine rebounds, and Annie
Anderson added 14 points and 16 rebounds.

The Bengals also switched to a zone defense in the second half.

"We said we cannot let one player beat us," said Newlee,
talking about the eight points, seven assists and seven rebounds by
MSU senior guard Sheila Hutchison in the first half. "That's why I
went to the zone because we were not picking her up in transition.
When she makes good decisions she's an awesome player, and she was
awesome tonight."

Hutchison ended her career at Montana State with a
tournament-first triple double -- 14 points, 11 rebounds and 14
assists -- including a pass to Joanna Hixon, whose basket tied the
score at 48 with 5:02 remaining.

"She tried so hard," said MSU coach Robin Potera-Haskins. "It
was like a one-woman show trying to win a ballgame as a senior. It
was great for our younger players to be around. If you're going to
end your career, that's the way to end it."

Hays hit a free throw, and Anderson completed a three-point play
to put ISU up 52-48 with 3:54 remaining.

MSU got within 52-51 on a steal and assist by Hutchison and a
basket by Hixon with 3:01 remaining.

A driving layup by Laraine Barron put Idaho State up 54-51 with
2:01 to play.

Montana State was forced to foul, and ISU made 9-of-10 free
throws in the final 1:13 to seal the victory.

The Bobcats were called for 26 fouls, and ISU made 25-of-34 free
throws.

ISU outrebounded Montana State 49-37, but made just 2-of-17
shots from 3-point range.

Hillary Scott had 15 points for Montana State, including several
athletic moves under the basket in the first half. Hixon fouled out
with 12 points and eight rebounds.
